EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.0   Introduction
BP Solvay Polyethylene North America (BP Solvay) is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for employees, the public, and the environment.  BP Solvay has established a system to help ensure safe operation of the processes at this facility.  One component of this system is a risk management program (RMP) that helps manage the risks at the Deer Park, Texas polyethylene plant.  The plant's program complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's Regulation 40 CFR 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Program (the RMP rule).  One of the requirements of the RMP rule is to submit a RMP Plan summary describing the risk management program at BP Solvay.  This plan is intended to satisfy the RMP Plan requirement of the RMP Rule (40 CFR 68.150 though 40 CFR 68.185) and to provide the public with a description of the RMP in place at BP Solvay.

2.0   Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
BP Solvay is committed to the safety of their employees, the public and to the preservation of the environment and has a program in place to prevent releases of hazardous substances. In the event of an accidental release, BP Solvay emergency response actions are in place to help prevent or minimize injury to the public or the environment.

3.0   Facility Process and Regulated Substances
BP Solvay manufactures polyethylene resins for a wide variety of industrial and consumer applications such as plastic milk bottles, pipes, and cups.
  
The polyethylene manufacturing process uses ethylene as the basic building block for producing polyethylene.  Isobutane is used as a carrier solvent for the polyethylene process.  Propane is inherent to the polyethylene manufacturing processes.  

4.0   Offsite Consequence Analysis
An offsite consequence analysis was conducted on the polyethylene facility.  The subject analysis consisted of worst-case scenario(s) and alternative release scenario

(s).

There is no toxic RMP compounds at the polyethylene facility; therefore, toxic worst-case and toxic alternative scenarios were not considered.
 
One worst-case scenario was completed for all flammable RMP compounds. The scenario is a release of 636,000 pounds of isobutane from two twin isobutane storage tanks and associated piping, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  The pressure effects from this scenario would reach the offsite industrial endpoints but it would not reach residential populations.

The worst-case scenario is considered a conservative analysis.  It is based worst-case meteorological conditions proposed by RMP guidance.  In addition, the worst-case scenario did not consider (credit) any existing safety systems or mitigation activities.  

Two Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS) were completed for flammable RMP compounds.  The first is a release of ethylene from a metering yard header resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  The second is a BLEVE of a polyethylene reactor containing 58,000 pounds of isobutane.  The pressure / thermal effects from these scenarios may reach offsite industrial endpoints but not residential populations.

The alternative release scenarios are based on more typical atmospheric conditions. 

5.0   Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The polyethylene processes are currently covered by the PSM standard.  As such, a Program Level 3 prevention program is in place.  The following paragraphs describe the prevention program elements at BP Solvay.

5.1   Safety Information 
BP Solvay maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to help ensure safe operations of the polyethylene processes.  Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) document the physical properties of all hazardous substances handled at the plant.  The engineering design documents include the operating parameters, the design basis and configuration of the equipment of the covered process, and references to applicable c

odes and standards.

5.2   Hazard Review 
BP Solvay will perform and periodically update hazard reviews of the processes to help identify and control process hazards.  Checklists include items to help ensure that BP Solvay operates and maintains the equipment in a manner consistent with the applicable design specifications, codes, standards, and regulations.

5.3   Operating Procedures 
BP Solvay operating procedures are maintained under an ISO9000 program.  As such we are required to develop and maintain operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operation should be performed.  The operating procedures are used to (1) train employees and contractors and (2) serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to take during both normal operations and process upsets.

5.4   Training 
BP Solvay trains personnel in the operating procedures to help ensure safe and effective performance of their assigned tasks.  A training documentation file is maintained to help ensure that refresher training is provided, as necessary.

5.5   Maintenance 
BP Solvay properly maintains the process equipment.  The maintenance program includes (1) procedures to safely guide workers in their maintenance tasks, (2) worker training in the maintenance procedures, and (3) an inspection and testing program to help identify equipment deterioration and damage before the equipment fails.

5.6   Management of Change 
BP Solvay has a program in place to document changes to facility processes.  A significant change in process chemicals, technology, equipment, practices or procedures prompt implementation of this program.  The program is designed to (1) evaluate the impact of the change on the process, (2) update records on the process and (3) ensure that workers are informed and trained on any significant changes.

5.7   Pre-startup Review 
BP Solvay performs audits on a new process or an existing process that has undergone a modification affecting the safety information.  This review is

done prior to operation of the modified process.  The review (1) confirms proper equipment was used, (2) safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are updated, (3) a hazard evaluation has been conducted, and (4) training has been updated.

5.8   Compliance Audits
BP Solvay performs periodic compliance audits of the covered process to verify that the process is operating in compliance with the Process Safety Management standard.  Compliance audit reports are prepared after each audit, with documented deficiencies and corrections.

5.9   Incident Investigations
BP Solvay investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment.  BP Solvay procedures require an investigation team to be assembled, and the investigation to be initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process enhancements are implemented.

5.10   Employee Participation
BP Solvay requires participation by the affected employees in development (1) of the process hazard evaluation, (2) process safety management, and (3) operating procedures of all covered processes.  The employees that work with or maintain the processes are given access to all information required under the rule.

5.11   Hot Work Permits
BP Solvay has written safety practices in place for fire protection and process operation.  A permitting system is used to prevent any unsafe acts on or around the covered process.

5.12   Contractors
BP Solvay reviews all contractors prior to working on or near a covered process.  The contractor must submit information that indicates the work can be performed competently and safely.  The company will provide information on the hazards of the process and the safety practices in place.  Documents are kept to confirm that the information was received and understood.  In addition, BP Solvay has procedures in place, which require

the entrance, presence, and exit of contractors to be controlled.

5.13   Chemical-specific Prevention Steps
In addition to engineering review and hazard analyses previously mentioned, workers who perform operations involving RMP listed compounds receive training emphasizing safe handling procedures developed by BP Solvay.  In addition, several equipment safeguards are in place.  Examples of such safeguards include: hydrocarbon detection and water deluge systems, related piping and vessel periodic inspection and maintenance, and continuous process monitoring for operations involving RMP listed compounds.
  
6.0   Five-Year Accident History
BP Solvay Polyethylene maintains a 5-year accident history that fulfills the requirements of the RMP rule (?68.42).  This history indicates a good record of accidental release prevention.  No releases of regulated substances above threshold quantity have occurred from BP Solvay during the subject five year period that have resulted in consequences of interest (i.e., deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site; or known deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage off site).

7.0 Emergency Response Program
BP Solvay has established a written emergency response plan that complies with the RMP rule and with other federal contingency plan regulations.  This plan has been communicated to local emergency response officials through the local police and fire departments.  Regular dialogue is maintained between the facility and the local response personnel, and the company provides appropriate information to the fire chief.  BP Solvay periodically conducts emergency response drills, including annual drills coordinated with the local response authorities.
 
8.0 Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Planned changes to improve safety are described in BP Solvay Process Hazard Analyses, plant alterations, projects, and the Site Safety, Health & Security Plan.
